docs.lead_paragraph: College students whose fathers were alcoholics showed an unusually strong preference for sugary tastes, a new study says, suggesting that an extreme sweet tooth may be added to the list of risk factors for drinking problems. The study's lead author, Dr. Alexey B. Kampov-Polevoy of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, said earlier research had shown that alcohol abusers tended to crave sweets more than most people. But that work had left it unclear whether the preference was a result of the substance abuse or reflected a genetic mechanism. Alcoholism is known to be a highly heritable trait.
docs.abstract: Dr Alexey B Kampov-Polevoy, Mount Sinai School of Medicine researcher, leads study published in journal Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research that finds children of alcoholic fathers have strong preference for sugary tastes; drawing (S)
